rsdscsdiff.long_name: Surface Diffuse Downwelling Clear Sky Shortwave Radiation

loadbc.comment: atmosphere mass_content of elemental carbon dry aerosol particles

loaddust.comment: atmosphere mass_content of dust dry aerosol particles

loadnh4.comment: atmosphere mass_content of ammonium dry aerosol

loadno3.comment: atmosphere mass_content of nitrate dry aerosol

loadpoa.long_name: Load of Dry Aerosol Primary Organic Matter
loadpoa.comment: atmosphere mass_content of primary particulate organic matter dry aerosol particles

loadso4.comment: atmosphere mass content of sulfate dry aerosol

loadsoa.comment: atmosphere mass_content of NULL dry aerosol

loadss.comment: atmosphere mass_content of seasalt dry aerosol particles

od550aer.long_name: Ambient Aerosol Optical Thickness at 550 nm
od550aer.comment: Ambient Aerosol Optical Thickness at 550 nm

sfo3max.long_name: Ozone volume mixing ratio in lowest model layer
sfo3max.comment: mole fraction of ozone in air

sfo3.long_name: Ozone volume mixing ratio in lowest model layer
sfo3.comment: Ozone volume mixing ratio in lowest model layer

sfpm25.long_name: PM2.5 mass mixing ratio in lowest model layer
sfpm25.comment: PM2.5 mass mixing ratio in lowest model layer

clt.comment: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

hfls.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface latent heat flux is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air on account of evaporation (including sublimation). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

hfss.comment: The surface sensible heat flux, also called turbulent heat flux, is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air by motion of air.

hur.comment: The relative humidity with respect to liquid water for T> 0 C, and with respect to ice for T<0 C.

hurs.comment: The relative humidity with respect to liquid water for T> 0 C, and with respect to ice for T<0 C.

hursmax.comment: The relative humidity with respect to liquid water for T> 0 C, and with respect to ice for T<0 C.

hursmin.comment: The relative humidity with respect to liquid water for T> 0 C, and with respect to ice for T<0 C.

hus.comment: Specific humidity is the mass fraction of water vapor in (moist) air.

mrro.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrro.comment: The total run-off (including drainage through the base of the soil model) per unit area leaving the land portion of the grid cell.

mrso.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrso.comment: the mass per unit area  (summed over all soil layers) of water in all phases.

mrsos.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
mrsos.long_name: Moisture in Upper Portion of Soil Column
mrsos.comment: The mass of water in all phases in the upper 10cm of the  soil layer.

pr.comment: includes both liquid and solid phases

prc.comment: Convective precipitation at surface; includes both liquid and solid phases.

prsn.comment: At surface; includes precipitation of all forms of water in the solid phase

rlds.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

rlus.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

rlut.comment: at the top of the atmosphere (to be compared with satellite measurements)

rsds.comment: Surface solar irradiance for UV calculations.

rss.comment: Net downward shortwave radiation at the surface

rsus.comment: The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics.

sfcWindmax.comment: Daily maximum near-surface (usually, 10 meters) wind speed.

snc.comment: Percentage of each grid cell that is occupied by snow that rests on land portion of cell.

snw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
snw.comment: The mass of surface snow on the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as missing where the land fraction is 0; excludes snow on vegetation canopy or on sea ice.

tasmax.comment: maximum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: max')

tasmin.comment: minimum near-surface (usually, 2 meter) air temperature (add cell_method attribute 'time: min')

tslsi.cell_methods: area: time: mean (comment: over land and sea ice)
tslsi.long_name: Surface Temperature Where Land or Sea Ice
tslsi.comment: Surface temperature of all surfaces except open ocean.

ua.comment: Zonal wind (positive in a eastward direction).

uas.comment: Eastward component of the near-surface (usually, 10 meters)  wind

va.comment: Meridional wind (positive in a northward direction).

vas.comment: Northward component of the near surface wind

wap.comment: Omega (vertical velocity in pressure coordinates, positive downwards)

zg.comment: Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.
